event.speaker:
Chia-liang Kao,  Co-founder, g0v.tw /Board Member, Open Culture Foundation
Dr. Rebecca Rumbul, Head of Research, mySociety(UK)
event.title: Welcome to TICTeC@Taipei and Civic Tech Fest

event.speaker: Dr Rebecca Rumbul, Head of Research, mySociety (UK)
event.title: What is Civic Technology? And how and why is mySociety measuring its impact?
event.abstract: Rebecca presents mySociety’s research projects which strive to evaluate the impacts (both positive and negative) of Civic Technologies in many countries worldwide.

event.speaker:
Chia-liang Kao, Open Culture Foundation (Taiwan)
Michael Canares, World Wide Web Foundation
Luke Bacon, Open Australia Foundation (Australia)
Gemma Humphrys, mySociety (UK) 
Nanjira Sambuli, Web Foundation (Kenya)
event.title: Examples of civic tech and its impacts from across the world
event.abstract: Now that the Civic Technology sector has matured, we can take a step back and assess its worth. What positive impacts have these tools had? How have they changed society and the relationships between citizens and governments? What negative impacts can be understood, and what is the best way to counter these for the future?

event.title: Fireside chat: Stephen King, Omidyar Network
event.abstract:
Stephen is a partner at the Omidyar Network, one of the most significant benefactors for those working in Civic Tech. 

Through the Governance & Citizen Engagement initiative, he oversees a portfolio that supports a broad range of organizations working in the US and around the world — including mySociety. 

Many are innovators in the use of technology to help make governments more responsive and aid citizens in holding their elected officials to account. In this session, we focus on why Civic Tech is important from a funder’s perspective, and what exactly they look for when it comes to making funding decisions.

event.speaker:
Nanjira Sambuli, Web Foundation (Kenya)
Chat Garcia Ramilo, Association for Progressive Communications, (Philippines)
James Powell, UNICEF Global Innovation Centre
Orianne Ledroit, French Digital Agency
event.title: How can Civic Tech reach more people? How can civic tech be more inclusive?
event.abstract:
Four speakers, with experience from around the world, present examples of technology projects that tackle digital exclusion. 
 
As a community, coders and activists must ensure that tools genuinely benefit the communities who need them most: leave with a practical checklist to make that happen.

event.speaker:
Erie Meyer, Code for American (USA) 
Mathilde Bras, Etalab (France)
Shu Yang Lin, The Public Digital Innovation Space (PDIS) (Taiwan)
event.title: Government-led Civic Technology: successes and challenges
event.abstract:
Individual activists or civic society organizations have traditionally led the way when it comes to Civic Technology projects — but increasingly governments are innovating in this sphere themselves. 
 
What are the advantages and disadvantages of citizen-to-government applications implemented by governments themselves? What success stories are there? And what can we learn from the challenges they’ve encountered?

event.note: To submit a lightning talk suggestion, please email: gemma@mysociety.org
